Pastel and black chalk on brown wove paper; 30.1 × 14.9 cm (11 7/8 × 5 7/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Walter Aitken, Margaret Day Blake, Harold Joachim Memorial, Celia and David Hilliard, Julius Lewis, and Sara R. Shorey endowments; Sandra L. Grung Fund; restricted gifts of William Vance and Pamela Kelley Armour; through prior acquisitions of Katherine Kuh, 2002.679

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">After enduring public humiliation following his libel suit against John Ruskin, bankruptcy, and the loss of his beloved White House, James McNeill Whistler retreated to Venice in September 1879. He left London armed with a commission from the Fine Art Society to produce twelve etchings of Venetian scenes, a £150 advance to cover living expenses, and an array of art materials. However, shortly after his arrival the city suffered its worst winter in thirty years; Whistler wrote to his sister-in-law Nellie, “It is of a cold you have no idea—cold way beyond anything I know in London.” The copperplates he worked on were “like ice,” making progress on the etchings difficult. Partly out of necessity, he turned to pastel, a medium more conducive to the challenging working conditions. Like the etching needles and plates, the materials he used for his pastel drawings were portable, enabling him to continue to work outdoors. Fellow artist Otto Henry Bacher, who became closely acquainted with Whistler that winter, recalled, “He always carried two boxes of pastels, an older one for instant use, filled with little bits of strange, broken colors of which he was very fond, and a newer box with which he did his principal work.” Whistler’s poverty and the need to live frugally may help explain this curious practice of carrying around an extra, older box of pastel fragments, but Bacher’s anecdote also testifies to the artist’s almost sentimental attachment to his materials. He drew with these on brown paper he had brought with him from London, as well as on other colored papers obtained in Venice.

Whistler struggled at first to find inspiration for his art among the city’s seemingly endless sources of material. Depictions of Venice’s historic sights were enormously popular in Victorian England, and many noted artists and writers, including Whistler’s adversary John Ruskin, had turned to the subject. Their portraits of the city in turn drew upon iconic images from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries by artists such as Antonio Canaletto (1697–1768), whose views of Venice’s monuments were especially admired by British audiences. Rather than revisiting these well-worn motifs, Whistler instead looked to the city’s backstreets, quiet canals, and unusual architectural features. Writing to the director of the Fine Art Society in January 1880, he excitedly pronounced, “now I have learned to know a Venice in Venice that the others never seem to have perceived.”

His use of pastels for these subjects was unorthodox. In the nineteenth century pastels were popular––particularly in France––for portraiture, but not necessarily for finished landscapes or cityscapes. Prior to Venice, Whistler had mainly confined his use of the medium to sketches of figures and studies for portraits. His technique also flew in the face of convention. Instead of following the usual practice of covering the paper in thick, blended layers of the powdery medium, Whistler’s approach was remarkably subtle, using color sparingly and leaving much of the paper visible. In fact, the paper becomes a color of equal importance to the composition as the pastels themselves. Though Whistler’s technique in the Venice pastels is in some respects very similar to his chalk-and-pastel figure drawings (see Study for “Arrangement in Black, No. 2: Portrait of Mrs. Louis Huth,” cat. 14; and A Nude Figure, cat. 18), the ambition of the Venice works far exceeds that of those earlier efforts. He was well aware of his pastels’ radical novelty, declaring them “something so new in Art that every body’s mouth will I feel pretty soon water.” Even after the weather turned warmer and he could resume work on his etchings, Whistler continued to make new pastel pictures, often switching between the two mediums over the course of a day.

Corte del Paradiso exemplifies the Venice pastels in both its subject and its application of materials. The setting is a small, ordinary courtyard off the Ruga Giuffa in the Castello district that is still in existence (fig. 22.1). Alastair Grieve describes it as a narrow, dark court surrounded by four- and five-story houses, and Margaret MacDonald notes that the area was decidedly working-class in Whistler’s day. It is therefore far from the type of scenic view of Venice to which Victorians were most accustomed. Whistler’s drawing captures the vantage point of a person standing at one end of the courtyard and looking down toward the facing facade at the far end, with the heaviest treatment concentrated on this most physically distant area of the composition. It renders many of the space’s architectural features, focusing attention on the repeating geometric patterns created by doorways, windows, and shutters. The vertical sweep of the tall buildings and the narrowness of the courtyard are further accentuated by the narrow dimensions of the paper. He balanced his emphasis on architecture with human details—the two children walking toward the viewer at left, the woman holding a baby in a doorway at right, and the colorful clothes hanging from various windows to dry––that define this as an inhabited space. This combined interest in architectural geometry and everyday humanity places Whistler’s Venice works in dialogue with genre subjects by other artists, particularly those of Dutch school painters such as Johannes Vermeer (1632–1675) and Pieter de Hooch (1629–1684) (see fig. 22.2 and fig. 22.3).

In his memoir, With Whistler in Venice, Bacher recounts Whistler’s drawing methods for the Venice pastels in detail: “In beginning a pastel he drew his subject crisply and carefully in outline with black crayon upon one of these sheets of tinted paper which fitted the general color of the motive. . . . He was never in a hurry in his work, always careful, and accomplished much. Some motives were finished at one sitting, but more often he made only the crayon outline, charming in its effect, leaving the unfinished sketch for days at its most fascinating point, to be filled in later with pastels. Many times these outlines needed very little color to complete them.” Whistler drew Corte del Paradiso on one of the sheets of brown paper from his original supply, brought over from London. The customary black-crayon outlines are readily apparent here, and, as Bacher observes, the colored pastels are employed to describe the spaces between these lines, enlivening without effacing them. Whistler’s unusually delicate handling of the colored pastels is especially notable in the broad sweep of white that covers the building at the center of the composition. The pastel skims lightly across the surface, drawing attention to the paper’s rough texture and subtly evoking the crumbling plaster of the building’s facade. Small notes of jewel-bright color animate the expanse of white, yet even these are applied sparingly, leaving much of the brown paper visible underneath. With his use of color, Whistler created a nuanced visual interplay between repetition and variety, weaving some colors throughout the composition while concentrating others, such as the bright-blue washing hanging from one window at left, in one or two specific areas on the sheet. One result of his subtle yet vibrant application of line and color is that it invites the eye to meander through the scene and discover its charming quotidian details. In effect, it replicates the experience of a tourist’s encounter with a typical Venice backstreet.

Having well overstayed the Fine Art Society’s original three-month assignment, Whistler returned to London in November of 1880 with around fifty etchings and over one hundred pastels, along with assorted drawings, watercolors, and oil paintings. A few months later, in January 1881, fifty-three of the pastels were shown at the Fine Art Society. As Lynne Bell has observed, the indeterminate status of the pastel medium in the British art world at the time made an exhibition dedicated to these works a daring venture. The gamble paid off; the show was a critical and financial success. Many critics were taken aback by Whistler’s unprecedented use of pastel, but most praised his originality and applauded the works’ reflection of “the true Venice that we all know—‘second-hand,’ dirty and everlastingly lovely.” One reviewer commented, “a man is said to ‘find himself’ when he hits on the right mode of expressing what genius he may have in him. In his ‘Venice Pastels’ at the Fine Art Company’s Rooms in Bond-street, Mr. Whistler has emphatically ‘found himself.’” The accolades were especially welcome given that Whistler’s exhibition of twelve Venice etchings, which had taken place a month earlier, had not received such a warm reception.

Attendees of the exhibition also admired the gallery’s décor, which Whistler had conceived to complement the pastels. In addition, Whistler designed the drawings’ frames to minimize the amount of empty space left visible around the edges, which intensified their visual impact (fig. 22.4; [M 758]). An inscription along the lower left side of Corte del Paradiso records the precise dimensions specified for its original frame. One admiring gallerygoer sketched all fifty-three of the pastels exhibited––Corte del Paradiso, entitled “Courtyard” in the exhibition catalogue, appears as number fifty-two (fig. 22.5). An original Venice Pastels exhibition catalogue from the Brewster Collection of Whistleriana now in the collection of the Ryerson and Burnham Libraries also contains pencil sketches of many of the works on display, including Corte del Paradiso (fig. 22.6). Priced at 25 guineas, it was one of the more affordable drawings on offer. Whistler, for his part, was reported to “[fear] his pastels are not so good as he supposed––for they are selling.”

Despite the triumph of the Fine Art Society exhibition, pastel did not begin to gain popularity in Britain as an artistic medium until later in the decade. This slow acceptance may partially explain why Whistler never attempted another project of this scale in pastel again. However, he may have simply felt that the Venice works represented an end in and of themselves, for, as he described to a friend, “the whole thing will be just a continuation of my own art work, some portions of which complete themselves in Venice.”

In 1877 Whistler had enlisted his friend, the architect Edward William Godwin, to build a custom-designed home and studio for him in London that became known as the White House. However, the financial strain placed on the artist by the higher-than-anticipated building costs, poor sales of his work, and his expensive lawsuit against John Ruskin, forced him to declare bankruptcy. In May 1879 he turned over possession of his home to bailiffs, who used the proceeds from the sale of the house to pay his creditors.

Grieve notes this connection to Dutch genre painting and includes Pieter de Hooch as an especially prescient example, as De Hooch’s The Courtyard of a House in Delft with a Woman and Child (fig. 3) was purchased by London’s National Gallery in 1871, and thus Whistler may well have seen it prior to his Venice sojourn. He also points out that the Pennells cite the work of the “Old Masters” as inspiration for Whistler’s Venice works. See Grieve, Whistler’s Venice, 35–36; and Pennell and Pennell, Life of Whistler, 1:276. Furthermore, one contemporary reviewer of the Venice pastels exhibition noted that the play of light in one of the works on display “carries one away to the works of the Dutchman De Hooghe now to be seen at the Royal Academy.” See “Mr. Whistler’s ‘Venice Pastels,’” Artist 2, no. 15 (Mar. 1, 1881): 72. As Nigel Thorp notes, Whistler owned a photograph of Vermeer’s View of Houses in Delft, Known as The Little Street (fig. 2). The photograph was taken in 1902, well after Whistler’s time in Venice, but, as Thorp observes, it confirms the artist’s “lifelong attachment to the Dutch school.” See Nigel Thorp, “Studies in Black and White: Whistler’s Photographs in Glasgow University Library,” Studies in the History of Art 19.
